perturbation.original_text:
A Party shall be liable to the other for loss, damage or delay to Freight due to its acts or omissions, including its negligence, and those of its employees, agents and those for whom in law it is responsible and occurring while Freight is in its care, custody or control. For the purpose of this Agreement, Freight shall be considered
in the care, custody or control of a Party from the time it is tendered
to it by the other Party or the other Party's customer until the time of
its delivery to the other Party or the consignee, as intended. For
greater certainty, a Party shall not be liable hereunder if the Freight
is damaged solely as a result of improper packing.
perturbation.changed_text: A Party may be liable to the other for loss, damage or delay to Freight due to its gross negligence. For the purpose of this Agreement, Freight shall be considered in the care, custody or control of a Party from the time it is tendered to it by the other Party or the other Party's customer until the time of its delivery to the other Party or the consignee, as intended. A Party shall not be liable hereunder if the Freight is damaged solely as a result of improper packing.
perturbation.explanation: By changing 'shall be liable' to 'may be liable' and limiting liability to 'gross negligence,' the contract reduces the carrier's responsibility for loss or damage. The original text includes liability for negligence, a standard required by Canadian law for common carriers. The change weakens the protection for the shipper. By only being liable for gross negligence, they are making it far harder to make a claim for loss of freight.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Canadian common law regarding carrier liability and negligence standards for freight transport.

perturbation.original_text:
Each Party shall purchase and maintain, at its own expense, the
following insurance coverages:

 (a) cargo liability insurance, subject to a combined single limit of
 not less than One Hundred Thousand dollars ($100,000.00)
 inclusive per occurrence. The other Party shall be named as an
 additional insured and the policy shall contain a cross
 liability clause;

 (b) automobile, non-owned automobile, fleet, comprehensive general,
 public and property liability insurance with a limit of not less
 than Two Million dollars ($2,000,000.00) inclusive of bodily
 injury and property damage for any one occurrence arising out of
 one (1) cause. The policy shall cover all non-air operations,
 non-owned automobile, contractual liability and liability
 specifically assumed under this Agreement. The other party shall
 be named as an additional insured and the policy shall contain a
 cross liability clause;
perturbation.changed_text:
Each Party shall purchase and maintain, at its own expense, the
following insurance coverages:

 (a) cargo liability insurance. The other Party shall be named as an
 additional insured and the policy shall contain a cross
 liability clause;

 (b) automobile, non-owned automobile, fleet, general,
 public and property liability insurance. The policy shall cover all non-air operations,
 non-owned automobile, contractual liability and liability
 specifically assumed under this Agreement. The other party shall
 be named as an additional insured and the policy shall contain a
 cross liability clause;
perturbation.explanation: Removing the 'combined single limit of not less than One Hundred Thousand dollars ($100,000.00) inclusive per occurrence' from the cargo liability insurance and 'with a limit of not less than Two Million dollars ($2,000,000.00) inclusive of bodily injury and property damage for any one occurrence arising out of one (1) cause' from the automobile liability insurance weakens the financial protection for the other party. The insurance amounts are not mentioned, making it so that the policy could be far less than expected, especially for a company that offers transportation services.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Standard insurance requirements for commercial transportation businesses operating in Canada, which typically mandate minimum coverage amounts.

perturbation.original_text:
Each Party shall deliver to the other, prior to commencing to provide
the Services and thereafter, annually, a certificate or certificates of
insurance evidencing that the required insurance coverages as
provided for in paragraph 9.1 are in effect and that each Party shall be
given thirty (30) days prior written notice of cancellation or
expiry of or material change to such insurance coverages.
perturbation.changed_text:
Each Party may deliver to the other, prior to commencing to provide
the Services, a certificate or certificates of insurance evidencing that the insurance coverages as provided for in paragraph 9.1 are in effect.
perturbation.explanation: By changing 'Each Party shall deliver' to 'Each Party may deliver' and removing the 'thereafter, annually' part and the 'that each Party shall be given thirty (30) days prior written notice of cancellation or expiry of or material change to such insurance coverages' section eliminates the requirement for ongoing proof of insurance and notification of changes. This weakens the other party's ability to verify and ensure continued coverage, creating a legal risk. The proof isn't even required, making it harder to make a claim if the coverage isn't adequate.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General principles of contract law requiring reasonable assurance of performance and adherence to insurance standards required for commercial transportation in Canada.
